title: News apps: how to make your audience care about your data
notes:
News apps: how to make your audience care about your data

Slides: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1epDxJdOEoDNW1IxU5G7Zq4kdXgWIXULAi6dBtAE_pkA

You've found this data story – how do you tell it?

	* Find people who exemplify it! 
	This helps you create empathy about issues that relate to your data set
	
	Examples: 
	http://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/21/us/milwaukee-segregation-wealthy-black-families.html?_r=1&mtrref=undefined&gwh=879B42F7415BEF7FE712EB5B8CF0CECE&gwt=pay
	
	* Allow people to explore it!
	This gives  people the opportunity to find their own story in the data. 
	
	Examples: 
	http://graphics.wsj.com/documents/student-debt-low-income/
	https://correctiv.org/en/investigations/nursing-homes/guide
	
	
	* Editorialize and visualize it!
	By doing some math and analysis and by visualizing your data, you can help your audience identify trends and anomalies
	
	Examples:
	http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/02/09/opinion/minimum-wage.html
	http://graphics.wsj.com/gender-pay-gap/
	
	* Make people play with it!
	By allowing people to play with the data, you give them agency over an outcome and you can help them understand how the datasets relate to one another
	
	Examples:
	http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/02/09/opinion/minimum-wage.html 
	https://projects.propublica.org/graphics/afghan
	
---

Definition: News Apps vs. News Graphics

Graphics tend to tell a single story while news applications tell many – specifically, news applications let readers see how they're personally affected.
— ProPublica Data Style Guide / https://github.com/propublica/guides/blob/master/news-apps.md
